fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:09): Darien do you know stuff about mysql_unbuffered_query?
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:10): Alterin_: I know stuff about unbuffered queries as a general topic
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:10): Darien should we use it when possible?
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:10): Alterin_: it can save memory, so it's not a bad idea
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:10): or it has a down side?
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:11): the downside of unbuffered queries is that you can't do random access
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:11): but increases load?
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:11): you have to operate on the first record, then the second, then the third, and so on
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:11): what do you mean by random acess?
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:11): well, you can't use record 23, then 14, then 39, then 82, then 12
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:11): or whatever
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:12): but if you're going to do that anyway, you can decrease memory usage dramatically, and increase performance because you don't have to wait
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:12): what if i retreive only one line?
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:12): well then it makes no difference whatsoever
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:12): 1, 2, 3, 4 are lines or columns?
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:13): normally what happens if you select (for example) 500 rows, is MySQL will get those 500 rows out of the database and then send them to you all at once
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:13): with unbuffered queries, it starts getting rows out of the database, and as soon as it has the first one it sends it to you
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:13): and then when it has the second, it sends it, and then the third, and so on
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:13): so you don't have to wait until MySQL has 500 rows, then wait until it sends them all to you over the network
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:18): Darien what do you do for a livin?
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:18): Alterin_: support analyst for a company that makes medical imaging management systems
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:19): hummm
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:19): important man
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:21): Darien is count much faster than a normal select?
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:22): much much faster
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:22): so it's better to make a count first and a normal select latter
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:22): is we want first to verify if it exists
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:23): that won't save you time
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:23): user login for example
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:23): SELECT TRUE FROM user WHERE username='foo' AND password='blah'
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:23): assuming you have an index on (username,password) then your entire users table is in memory already
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:23): and so you never have to hit the disk
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:24): but imagine
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:24): we get if its banned, and other stats so that we can show them right away
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:25): but it can be no user so we are trying to get that info for nothing
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:25): a count to verify
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:25): and then a get for the info
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:25): sorry
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:25): very cofusing
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:26): ok, let me put it this way
f6b127e38214e484df709cbee84fa242 (08:26): In Soviet Russia, MySQL queries YOU
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:26): doing A is faster than B
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:26): doing A then B is slower than doing eithe rone
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:26): especially if you can do one query that does both
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:26): so A+B in one is always better
fa09e159d3aa53d95b8041a384a5fad9 (08:27): even if you are trying to get data that doesn't exist
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:27): because if you do A and it doesn't exist, its' just as fast as doing B and it doesn't exist
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:27): because it's only using the index anyway
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:28): so it's doing the same work in both queries
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:28): if it scans the index and doesn't find the row, it's not going to hit the disk, it'll just give up
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:28): if it scans the index and finds the row, then it doesn't have to scan the index again on the next query
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:28): the general rule is that the fewer SQL queries you're doing, the better
46b908401111ea4fd08e643e2db3534f (08:29): because then you also avoid a round-trip to the server and back, plus the overhead of parsing the SQL query, locking the table for read, and so on

8aaafd012aa3c6f6ec29062b2634a3bd (08:49): After Adding a record in a transaction How can I retrive the ID
8aaafd012aa3c6f6ec29062b2634a3bd (08:50): with php you get it using mysql_insert_id()
8aaafd012aa3c6f6ec29062b2634a3bd (08:51): anyway, how can I get it with SQL ?
13c8bdd77825acbfb0548a044efdc141 (08:59): blaBla, SELECT LAST_INSERT_ID();
